During his tenure as the President of the Tunica County, Mississippi Branch of the NAACP, he worked tirelessly to integrate public schools and businesses in Tunica.  Simultaneously, Mr. Norwood worked to register citizens to vote in the late 1960s.

Mr. Calvin C. Norwood was a community activist, husband, father, and WWII Navy Veteran.  He dedicated his life to service and making people live up to the sign as you enter the town, “Tunica a good place to live.” In 1963 Mr. Norwood he participated in the March on Washington. pic.twitter.com/EarTBNwEd5

Additionally, Mason played a role in COFO’s massive black voter registration drive, the Freedom Summer of 1964. Also, he served as president of the Mississippi NAACP for thirty-three years. #LiberatorsoftheMagnolia
It was not decided until 1968 when the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Mississippi beaches were public and had to be desegregated by federal law.

Mason filed the first school desegregation lawsuit in the history of Biloxi, which he also won.  A legal challenge to the segregation had been initiated by the U.S. Department of Justice in May 1960 but had been delayed in getting a court hearing.

Mason led a third wade-in protest at the beach in spring 1963, two weeks after the funeral for Medgar Evers. The protesters faced a much larger group of nearly 2000 white protesters, but this time the police prevented violence against them.

These resulted in a successful anti-discrimination lawsuit against the state of Mississippi, the first such case filed in U.S. history. They were attacked by groups of whites across the beaches as the Biloxi police stood by without taking action.

He led a nonviolent protest against the “whites only” section of a federally funded Gulf Coast beach.  Mason’s group was arrested.  Subsequent “wade-ins” ignited some of the bloodiest white riotings in Mississippi history.
He is most notable for organizing and participating in Mississippi's first nonviolent civil disobedience action, known as the Biloxi wade-ins, which took place from 1959 to 1963.
Dr. Gilbert R. Mason, Sr. was a physician who was known as the “wade-in” activist.  Mason started a family practice in Biloxi, Mississippi, in 1955. pic.twitter.com/cffu0OvjEa

At that moment, Celestine King stepped out of line and started running and all the students followed. #LiberatorsoftheMagnolia

They were met by the police officers who formed a circle around the students asking for the name of the leader of the demonstration, but no one spoke.  The officers informed the students that they would release dogs on them.

Despite the president of the university’s wishes, the students organized a peaceful walk to pray for the students of Tougaloo who were arrested for participating in a demonstration to integrate the city library in Jackson, MS.  At the time the city’s library was “whites only.”
Celestine King participated in the first demonstration to end segregation in the Jackson State University’s history.  She was a student at the university during the 1960s. pic.twitter.com/VeqSVdgQWI
Happy Birthday @RepBonnie!

He was the first African- American to hold office since the Reconstruction Era.  Also, he remained the only African- American until 1976 and was repeated reelected until 2003. In 2004, he became the first African-American to have a Mississippi State building named after him.

Mr. Clark and the Freedom Democratic Party is responsible for having registered thousands of black voters for the first time after reconstruction.  Robert G. Clark was elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1967.

In 1963, he began working to register and educate voters. He became a candidate in the Freedom Democratic Party in 1967 because of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 which prohibited racial discrimination in voting.

Clark received his bachelor’s degree from @JacksonStateU and his Masters in Administration and Education Services from Michigan State University.  His Ph.D. was almost completed before he decided to devote his time to pursue politics.

Robert G. Clark Jr. impacted the lives of many during his tenure as a teacher in Holmes County, MS. His family was trailblazers in economic development because they became landowners immediately following the American Civil War. pic.twitter.com/kaOxF4jtEp

As mayor, she oversaw the construction of several sets of public housing, the first time that federal housing had been built in Issaquena County. Furthermore, she gained national attention by traveling across the country to promote the construction of low-income housing.

During her time participating in the Civil Rights Movement, she was jailed over 70 times because of her role in civil rights protests and other actions.
She was elected mayor of Mayersville, MS in 1976, making her the first female African-American mayor in Mississippi.

Later that year, she became a member of the executive committee of the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party. In late August, she and 67 other elected Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party delegates traveled to the 1964 Democratic National Convention.

She first got involved in the Civil Rights Movement in June 1964, when two activists from SNCC came to Mayersville.  After meeting Fannie Lou Hamer in the summer of 1964 and hearing her experiences in the Civil Rights Movement, Blackwell decided to join the SNCC.

Unita Zelma Blackwell is a civil rights activist.  Blackwell was a project director for the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee and helped organize voter drives for African Americans across Mississippi. pic.twitter.com/UswZmucDYY
This year for Black History Month, I will be highlighting unknown civil rights heroes of Mississippi.   Email all submissions to magnolialiberators@mail.house.gov. pic.twitter.com/9ecSBlokri
Happy Birthday to the “Mother of the Civil Rights Movement,” Rosa Parks! pic.twitter.com/3ODAF6IaoK

From her contributions to the law to her contributions to the community, Ms. Slaughter-Harvey fights for all humanity—protecting the interests of not only African-Americans but also all the underprivileged and downtrodden. #LiberatorsoftheMagnolia
As its president, she supervises an after-school tutorial/enhancement program where she spends her free time teaching and mentoring children at risk.

In a state that ranks 50th among the states in the percent of children who are poor, Ms. Slaughter-Harvey continues to direct her personal and professional efforts to assist minority and poor youth through the Slaughter Memorial Foundation.

She filed a desegregation suit against the highway patrol, which resulted in the hiring of African American highway patrolmen. Ms. Slaughter-Harvey’s dedication to civil rights did not end with the struggles of the ‘60s and ‘70s.

Slaughter-Harvey was inspired by the brutal death of Medgar Evers, whom she met as a student at @TougalooCollege. After graduating from law school, she represented the families of the 2 students who were brutalized and killed by highway patrolmen in 1970 at @JacksonStateU.

Constance Slaughter-Harvey is a civil rights icon in Mississippi. She was the first African-American judge in Mississippi and the first African American female to graduate from @olemisslaw. pic.twitter.com/46Z7xDWYbd
